name: computer production, desktop, without screen | computer, desktop, without screen | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/3193/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 unit of desktop computer. The data represent a typical desktop computer used at home or in an office. The data sources are mainly based on weighing and calculations at EMPA laboratories.Material data are taken from own measurements of a typical computer, examined at the EMPA laboratories, type Mandax Pentium 4, built in 2002. (Pentium 4, processor speed 2000 MHz, 40 GB RAM HDD, 512 MB working memory, total weight without screen and cardboard packaging 11.3 kg).   Computer parts like Graphic card, Network card, Hard disk drive, CD Rom drive, Power supply unit, Printed wiring boards (e.g. motherboard) and batteries are inventoried in individual datasets. ;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of raw materials and auxiliaries at the factory gate.

This dataset includes the materials (mainly metals and plastics) with their respective manufacturing processes (e.g. sheet rolling or blow moulding). Further inventoried is the infrastructure (factory), the electricity for the assembly of the desktop computer, the water consumption and industrial waste water, the required ship, rail and road transport for input materials, the packaging, plus the disposal of the computer.
category: C:Manufacturing/26:Manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products/262:Manufacture of computers and peripheral equipment/2620:Manufacture of computers and peripheral equipment

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The data is based on weighing a typical desktop computer at the EMPA laboratories in St. Gallen. Such a desktop computer like other PC brands may be assembled anywhere in the world.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The production of a desktop computer includes the steel processing steps rolling, cutting, mill cutting, and coating. Plastic parts are blow moulded or extruded into required shapes. The process technology of the parts (capacitors, resistors, microchips etc.) mounted onto the printed wiring board are described in the individual datasets.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Own measurements at laboratory (weighing) and manufacturer information.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
Constructed of different datasets: refined material input: e.g. steel, aluminium, PP, processing of materials: e.g. sheet rolling, die casting, press moulding, entire components: e.g. Hard Disk Drive, CD Rom Drive, battery, populated and unpopulated PWBs: includes e.g. ICs, capacitors, resistors, diodes, expansion slots (for populated PWB), energy for computer assembly: electricity, medium voltage, production UCTE, water consumption, emissions, waste: e.g. industrial waste water, transport: transport by transoceanic freight ship as well as 32 t lorry and rail for computer parts from regional storage to production plant (ecoinvent standard transport distances), 	infrastructure, Packaging: cardboard and PP (or PS/PE), disposal: disposal of computer and packaging to WEEE treatment.
